results.abstract: Czechs are divided on whether radar for missile defense system proposed by US against possible Iranian attack on Europe should be installed in their country; many say radar would make Czech Republic a target and do not want to keep doing America's bidding; others embrace idea of American presence; in Poland, proposed missile interceptors, part of same system, are unpopular, but have not become serious public issue; map; photos (M)

headline.main: Many Czechs Love U.S., But Say 'Hold the Radar'

results.snippet: The Czech population is deeply divided over whether its country should host a controversial U.S. missile-defense radar system that is opposed by Russia.

byline.original: By NICHOLAS KULISH; Katerina Zachovalova contributed reporting

results.lead_paragraph: To understand just how divisive the proposed American missile-defense radar system is here, talk to Josef Rihak. Better still, talk to both of them. Josef Rihak, 48, the father of Josef, 18, is a member of the Czech Parliament who in 2003 voted to send troops to Iraq. He is now also mayor of Pribram and coordinator of the League of Mayors Against the Radar, a 35-member group opposed to the installation of the system on Czech soil.
